review_title: Great way to get your foot in the door
job_title: Service Desk Administrator II in Cleveland, OH
pros: Great pay. Great PTO. Great culture. I felt appreciated and important despite going in with no degree or experience. Once I got over the (steep) learning curve the job becomes almost boring. The level II position is a great way to interact with other facets of IT, especially if you're a person still unsure of what direction you're looking to take when it comes to specialization.
cons: HR is abhorrent here. You will wait anywhere from 2-7 months to be hired by HR, and moving any position (even within your department) requires the input of HR, regardless of how qualified you may or may not be. This is also a several month long process. This makes it difficult to recruit actual talent, rather than someone who just has the ability to wait 4 months to get hired somewhere. You cannot receive more than a 10% raise in a year unless you are promoted. HR also has a say in promotions. The same HR person manages recruiting at specific departments so if you somehow annoy the HR person for your department. You're never going anywhere. Many people I know have left UH for a year, and came back later to command a higher salary since it is nigh impossible to convince Finance that you're worth paying more.

review_title: Please save yourself time, and stay away from this job
job_title: Home Health Aide in Warrensville, OH
pros: The schedule coordinator Valerie Parcell is the only component of this institution that kept me going for the months I was there, as she is a genuine and kind individual that continuously illustrates that she cares and shares the pain of what the aids are put through. Also, I really loved working with the diverse geriatric demographic and learning about their stories and backgrounds.
cons: The worse paid per patient model an employee could experience. Constant visit cancellations and not enough patients to serve due to hospitalizations and other factors. That being said, I biweekly made 50-70% of what I expected when I signed their contract with putting 40 hours a week of work. Management will force you to drive to places like Ashland ( from central Cleveland ) that is a whopping 1,5 hours away one way to serve 3-5 patients a shift. During the months I was there, I put so many miles on my car, but management will constantly point out how attractive the millage reimbursement check is which, hello! pretty much is just covering the high gas cost and will not leave any money to cover car utilization costs. It didn’t matter how many times I talked to management or even the educational department that trained me, they just smiled, and blamed the pandemic and nothing ever changed. This is the only job I’ve ever had (and I’ve been working for about a decade now) that actually put me in financial issues because I was not making enough to cover simple costs of living and was charging up my credit card to cover basic stuff like grocery or utilities bills. On the other hand, I was still making “too much” to qualify for services are food stamps and other assistant programs. Please save yourself some stress and anxiety and run away from this heartless institution.

I should mention that the manager is a micro manager as well.

He's accomplished, proven, a motivator and genuinely cares about his team.  I believe he also has the respect of his peers, which has not been the case with previous CMOs.  Furthermore, proven and successful leaders in Marketing, Physician Relations and Market Research have been brought in to take the Department and Hospital to new heights, and the results are already being seen.  While senior leaders in the department - they all have displayed from day 1 a 'roll up your sleeves' and get the job done attitude which is a breath of fresh air. review_title: Humanistic Objectives for Employees with Type A Managers
pros:
Many people will do well there. The main matter is conforming to the managers' methods. There are many excellent employees.

There are inspiring leaders at the top and its competition with the Cleveland Clinic is a great prompt to doing more better.

The reasons to work there are probably about the same for any region-wide hospital system. My perspective is from the IT perspective. Time and money were being invested in software to better manage the revenue cycle. Corresponding time and resources were used to reorganize the operation of scheduling and billing.

I largely down tick the organization for how I was treated as an individual contributor.
cons:
Diversity meant conforming to the UH policies more than it meant allowing parties with different perspectives to operate productively together.

My perspective is from IT. Senior management encourages contemporary management principles while the project I participated in was run by someone who did not appreciate suggestions from staff and was overqualified for the role she assumed as an interim project manager. 

Software vendors are treated as gods compared to IT staff.Much of IT is already outsourced. 

Administrative functions are scattered among many buildings across the Case Western Reserve University campus and beyond. Each department is its own little fiefdom in terms of hiring and firing. Individuals may be given little opportunity to find work with a different manager if the first doesn't work out.

There were charges for parking at the main campus and not elsewhere.

pros: I really like working at UH.  Much lower than average amount of personality issues compared to other places I've been.  On the whole senior leaders and mid-level leaders are very competent.  I think the CEO, Tom Zenty is very competent and a great leader - he put into effect a strategic plan that really turned the place around compared to before he came.  Salary and benefits seem slightly above average.  Most everyone seems to genuinely care about the patients that we serve.
cons: Well, not that I don't love Cleveland, but it's Cleveland.  Also, like most health care providers UH is studying ways to control costs and prepare for the future of healthcare - this can lead to periodic cost cutting, which often doesn't mean cuttting people but sometimes does.

job_title: Senior Dataabse Administrator in Cleveland, OH
pros: Competitive salaries based on region and industry
cons:
Terrible benefits. Retirement plan barely qualiifies as a retirment plan. 3% cash balance fund. And retiree hospitalization is $1500 a month for an employee and spouse. And the current hospitalization plan is no way an attraction for employees of a medical institution. Tuition reimbursement provides half the value of competitiors. 
Many middle managers are ineffective and subscribe to no recognizable style or approach.  Management communication is non existant. Managers are consitantly reactive and blame is a management style keyword here as opposed to assumption of responsibility. If you thrive on chaos then University Hospitals will be a great fit for you.

pros:

cons: The pay is low. The health benefits are astronomically priced. Many department managers of recently acquired regional hospitals are resistant to change or growth and are stuck on the way their hospital operated before being acquired by UH. This makes moving forward into a new era of healthcare a challenge.

review_title: With Great Responsibility Comes Great Stress...?
pros:
I enjoy my job because I am constantly learning and helping to educate others. From the macro perspective this job might seem repetitive, however with the micro perspective each encounter you code will be different. A different patient and a different story waiting to be read. 

Perks:
-1 year of onsite training to guide you through the coding process
-Ability to work remote (from home)
   -After the 1 year of training you are eligible
-Higher starting pay and pay increases with certifications (RHIA, RHIT, CCS, etc)
   -(seriously, get at least one certification before apply, it will help you immensely)
   -Yearly pay increases
-The Health, Dental & Vision plans available to UH employees
-Friendly coworkers and pleasant environment.
cons:
The only downsides/issue I have with this job is the expectations that are laid out which set you up for failure. 

-Expected to maintain 95% on accuracy
   -This means that you have to spend some time on each case, which may include:
     -Researching conditions/diseases that you are unfamiliar with
     -Researching procedures that you are unfamiliar with in order to understand
     what is being done so that you are able to accurately code the procedure(s).
   -Communicating with CDIS (Clinical Documentation Improvement Specialists.
       -These are former nurses who decided to enter the coding world.
       -They have a lot of clinical knowledge, but as the coder you are expected to
       know/know how to find coding clinics or other guidelines that govern what you
       can and can't code.
       -You may have to ask the CDIS a question, or ask for them to send a query to a
       physician, your codes may not match theirs and you have to settle it by proving
       your coding with sound logic and reasoning.

-Expected to hit pre-established standards for the amount of productive work you
complete within a 2 week period.
   -When off training you are expected to have 70 productive hours worth of work
     - 70 hours work out of the 80 you're there doesn't sound too bad
         -There are predetermined ranges of an encounter'd Length Of Stay (LOS)
            - For instance, 1-3 day stays are allotted 32.5 minutes
               -This means that no matter how long it takes you to code an encounter,
                from start until submission, you are only "awarded that amount of time."
               -You could have an encounter that is not very complex and the
                documentation is clearly stated, and it may only take you 20 minutes to
                complete, you were awarded more time than it actually took you.
                -Or.... You could get an encounter that is very complex, the documentation
                is very vague and you have to discuss with a CDIS to get their perspective
                and ask them any questions you might have, and possible have to ask them
                to get the provider to document something.

-Now that you have the pressure of coding accurately so that you don't fall below the required 95% accuracy, (which will result in an "occurrence," with each occurrence you rise on the punishment ladder) you also have the pressure of getting enough time in to hit the required amount of productive work for that period.
     -This can force some to either code to quickly and miss things and their accuracy suffers, or they take their time to code accurately, however by doing so they do not meet the requirement for productive work for that period.

review_title: Great Place to work, moves a million miles an hour
pros: UH began a plan to revitalize itself in 2001, called Vision 2010... By 2010 it did that and much more!  Today it is a powerhouse of healthcare, medicine, research and teaching...  It truly is a place where it treats its patients with Advance Care and Advance Caring. A+++ in my books
cons: No cons come to mind at all.  If you want to work hard, be rewarded for your work and advance, UH is great.  If you are lazy and dont embrace technology, and advancement, well then stay home!

review_title: I truly enjoyed working at University Hospitals of Cleveland, Main Campus
pros: Autonomy as a Manager.  Culture was great.  Chance for advancement (if not at main campus, then up to other healthcare campuses)
cons: Good-ole-boys networking.  Loyalty to advance employees who should not be advanced when newer staff are more qualified.  Management that has been in place a long time who are ineffective.

review_title: University Hospitals of Cleveland offers many opportunities for advancement...if you're willing to work for it.
pros: UH is a great place to work if you want to get into the medical field, but aren't sure what to specialize in.  UH is a teaching hospital, so you get to see a lot of different specialties going on, i.e.- nursing, physician, radiology, phlebotomy, etc.  The work/life balance is great because when you're outta there, you're outta there...unless you're senior management or something, you can pretty much leave work and not have to worry about it at home.  Pay is good and comparable to other hospitals...I make $13.06/hr plus $.80 shift differential for being a Nursing Assistant and I've only been there 2 1/2 years.  If you get on a good floor with good people, that makes it that much for enjoyable to be at work for a whole shift.
cons: Some downsides are the amount of work one has to do some days.  I work at night, so the level of patient need is obviously lesser than daytime, but still it can get busy.  Some staff only think of it as a job and don't offer the same care and compassion as others, but I think you'll get that attitude wherever you work.  My managers are pretty lousy in the sense that I don't get much feedback on how I'm doing other than my yearly review.  But then again, they are usually gone by the time I get to work and I don't even see them when I leave in the morning.

review_title: Very good experience, if you are willing to learn you can maximize your potential.
pros: Growth, you can continue to advance your career and use your talents. Company includes employees in their acheivements, with acknowledgements, bonuses, shared celebrations. There are many opportunities to find good positions, once you are in the system you can transfer to where you are best suited.
cons: I have not really had any downsides though working as a PRN full-time was a challenge.

job_title: Patient Access Representative in Cleveland, OH
pros: The benefits are awesome, PTO is great. And there are many opportunities for career advancement. Also there are many different locations to apply at.
cons: Once you accept a position you are locked in for 1 year. The only other way to apply to a different position is with a waiver from your supervisor or manager.

pros: Some of the funniest, kindest people work at University Hospitals.  The people who work there genuinely do care about the mission and what they are trying to achieve.
cons: Stay in your lane is a very common phrase to hear.  There is little room for expanding your skill set and going above and beyond feels frowned upon.  Management has trouble processing any sort of extra step you try to take for the better of the department and views it as causing confusion or looks at it as poor you having to work more, despite telling them how excited you are to be a part of this project. Every step of a project needs run up the ranks and regardless of your own title and being told to "drive" a project, all decisions must really come from higher up.  You can predict the outcome weeks before they are decided, but still must wait for final say before moving forward.  Ownership of your own work is not allowed.

review_title: Good mission, bad health benefits, doctors get special treatment
pros:
Good mission, coworkers, place is growing, attempts to improve compliance and diversity culture. Annual reviews are general plans for future and review of success instead of ratings/rankings that leave you feeling demoralized.

Wellness program can potentially earn you $600/year for yourself AND your spouse, but takes genuine effort.

Some bad managers have actually been given the boot in order to improve things.

You can sell your unused PTO. 

Compliance seems to be making a good effort in educating employees about preventing errors and reporting problems. I hope they have the power to go up against the culture there.

Free exercise classes (if you can get in.)

Opportunities to move up. Tend to hire from within.
cons:
Physicians too often are treated like gods and people are afraid to hold them accountable. 

Health care forces you to only get care from their doctors and at an unreasonable price. High deductible is only affordable option, then you avoid ever going to the doctor or getting prescriptions. 

Subtract 6 days from your PTO because you are forced to use it for holidays. 

Old habits are hard to break, especially when powerful doctors are involved. There are people trying to improve things, but people at the top are slow to act or listen to little people who know what they are talking about. Too many people at top get their feathers ruffled too easily if corrected or offered advice. 

Overly corporate feel. Top leaders talk about money too much,  making you feel like the things you are passionate about that make you enjoy your job (like helping people, doing the right thing) aren't valued, just  faster, more money, bigger numbers, now!

Maternity/paternity leave options could be better. You can never save more than one year's worth of PTO at a time, so unless you pay extra for full disability insurance, you are screwed if you have a baby or unexpectedly need out for medical reasons.

Parking expensive on main campus. Also, safety concerns. People don't learn about various muggings and car jackings unless they know people at CWRU.

pros: I was PRN so I could make my own schedule.
cons: Coworkers were soo lazy and all of the work fell on people who actually worked. Management constantly belittled us. Coworkers are rude and discuss unprofessional and inappropriate matters constantly at work. Very cliquey environment. Turnover rate was so high that for the short time I was there a lot of people quit. Other departments hated the department I was in and didn’t wanna hire people from my department.

pros: UH has some nice benefits. The pay is okay for unlicensed folks. The PTO is awesome. You get 8 hours for every 80 worked. The schedules are flexible, depending on your nursing manager, and theres TONS of opportunities for upward mobility. The pay for educational advancements, work around your educational and family schedule, and even encourage you to go to school. In following the nursing career pathway, youll be offered a job as an RN guarenteed (so long as youre not a dirtbag) The pension is okay, and the 404(b) isnt terrible either. The management cares about its employees and are all about allowing you your space to spread your wings.
cons: They almost get too pushy about school. Which I guess isnt quite a bad thing, but I feel like Im working with my ma back when I was in high school. They (the RNs you work with) are sometimes your teachers...and will hunt you down to quiz you, or drag you away from your duties to see something that was discussed in class that day. That gets a little annoying. The other bad thing is the insurance. It kinda sucks. Its expensive, and the HSA doesnt pay for squat. The PPO plan is okay, if youre okay,with coughing up $300 per pay if you have a family if its just you, its actually really affordable. The parking at the Case campus is an absolute nightmare. Its too expensive, people dont follow the rules, and theres zero enforcement. Although in UH's defense they dont run the garages, University Circle does...but still...The other obnoxious thing is that theres always some type of "party"...Either its someones birthday, or someone got promoted, or took a new job, or had a baby, or is getting married, or whatever. They have us bring stuff in like a potluck seriously like every other week. The other annoying part is holidays. You HAVE to work your assigned holidays. There is no trading, no PTO (especially at Christmas) and the deal is if you work Thanksgivong, you get Christmas Day and New Years day off. If youre off Thanksgiving, you work Christmas Eve, and and New Years Eve...but it is holiday pay (time and a half plus $5 an hour incentive)

If you have any pride in what you do or care about the product you put out DO NOT work here. It is just ciaos.

pros: Large, recognizable name in a good industry
cons:
My Experience at UH was terrible.

Within first week of hire was told the million $ platform I was responsible for could not perform any of the items listed in my job description and they attempted to pivot me to something completely different.

Management used gaslighting, manipulation, coercion, and intimidation to try and force me into other responsibilities. Was told that the departments was a “difficult” place to work when I complained about harassment and the hostile work environment. Below are just a few examples:

Directors shamed me in from of colleagues for responsibilities that were explicitly in someone else’s job description.

A colleague threatened me by saying management will “break me”.

Females exposed themselves to me in order to create anxiety before management tried to give me their work.

Management contacted my family and telling them “I was not doing my job” to try and make me do things well outside my job description.

Police barged in on a meeting I was in an attempt to make again induce anxiety and make me feel that I was in trouble.

Once the 3 year contract for the platform was nearly done, management began writing me up for various “performance issues”. These included things like not producing consistent reports after I had been asked to adjust them then made said changes, and not completing project tasks that were assigned to someone else.

In essence, management failed to properly implement a million-dollar system and I was the scapegoat.

This was during the same time frame as the UH Fertility incident, where basically the cryogenic system failed and was not repaired, the backup cryo system failed and was not repaired, then the audible alarm that alerted someone it was time to add additional coolant literally with a bucket failed, destroying 1000’s of eggs/embryos. They are currently fighting multiple lawsuits of negligence which they deny although it's clear they were negligent with the maintenance of a critical system. I think this speaks to the UH’s culture and management style that I experienced, which was one of disorder, ineffectiveness, incompetence, and negligence with an deliberate ignorance to having responsibility for any of it.
